explanation_composer.regulatory_rule_cue:
Traffic Separation Scheme (TSS) Lane Discipline — Applicable to cargo vessels navigating within structured maritime corridors — Spatial Anchor: Unnamed traffic separation scheme
Operational Protocol Rationale: Cargo vessels operating in traffic separation schemes are expected to maintain stable speed and course along designated routes to ensure predictable, safe passage among high-density shipping lanes. The observed vessel, being of typical cargo dimensions and without hazardous cargo, aligns with standard navigation practices by following a fixed, linear trajectory with minimal heading deviation—indicative of autopilot-assisted transit under TSS compliance. This behavior prioritizes collision avoidance and route adherence over maneuverability, ruling out more dynamic patterns such as anchoring, docking, or evasive turning. Although the immediate path shows south-southeast progression, the selection of a northeast-oriented reference pattern is justified by the prevalence of similar kinematic profiles across directional segments within the same regulatory zone, where consistent motion dynamics override absolute bearing. Linear interpolation is therefore appropriate for gap-filling, as it reflects the expectation of uniform motion under regulated conditions.
